Since I mentioned it last week and before anybody tries to accuse of
bluffi=
ng about working on a version of Gladiator written in Java, I
will promise =
that is at the top of my list of programming stuff to do.


**So far off-to=
pic that ain't funny**
You might wonder what the heck is in front of it.  L=
ately, I've been
using Java to graph mathematical equations. 
http://home.w=
indstream.net/melvinsh/applets/dph-applets.htm - a list
of my applets.  Any=
ways, what I'm trying to graph a math equation.

Imagine that you have 5 po=
ints (p1 - p5) randomly located on a graph.
 Then you pick another point (p=
6) and find out that if you took the
sum of the distance from p1 to p6, the=
 distance from p2 to p6, the
distance from p3 to p6, the distance from p4 t=
o p6, and the distance
from p5 to p6 is a constant c.  You might wonder wha=
t other points
beside p6 fit the same criteria that p6 fits.  That's what I=
'm trying
to graph.  Since distance taking square roots, I wasn't happy wit=
h
that because it eliminates potential points.  So using algebra I've
expan=
ded the equation to eliminate all the square roots.  The
resulting expansio=
n is 3 1/4 pages double spaced.  The math is so
bad/complex that I had to u=
se a website to help me expand it -
http://www.quickmath.com/ .  Entering 3=
 1/4 pages of mathematical
expressions without typos is . . difficult.  The=
 good news is I'm
halfway through double checking the expressions for error=
s.
**End so far off-topic that ain't funny**

What I plan on doing first is=
 getting some basic graphics to work:

ct dimensions - I already did

) on the map.
